Description: Mould-made pottery lamp with a double-convex body, a short round-topped splayed nozzle, and a raised circular base, flat below with a deep groove, and with an impressed letter alpha. The filling-hole is surrounded by two moulded rings, the outer one being surrounded by a horse-shoe of egg-and-tassel decoration in relief. Between the nozzle and the moulding is a scroll pattern. The shoulder is decorated with radiating grooves. There is a plain lug on the right side, and one in the form of a dolphin on the left. The top of the nozzle has a short transverse groove. Decorated with an orange-brown slip. Fine cream fabric with very fine black, white and mica inclusions <0.2mm.
Curator's comments: Egyptian form copying Knidian types found in Athens (Howland 1958, Type 40A; Bailey 1975, 260). Variant of Mlynarczyk's Type M, dated from the end of the 2nd to the mid 1st century BC (Mlynarczyk 1997, Type M-Prime b.1, see Photo 23). Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton. Mlynarczyk, J. 1997. Alexandrian and Alexandria-influenced mould-made lamps of the Hellenistic period. BAR International Series 677.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q559)
Walters 1914 / Catalogue of Greek and Roman Lamps in the British Museum (303)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.032) (Phase 1)
